captions.text: ♪♪(music playing)♪♪

Diana Skaar:
Those who have never been inside
the White House will basically

be able to experience the same
tour that you would get if you

were able to come here
for the public tour.

So using the same technology
that we use for Street View,

we're using that technology
indoors so that people will be

able to walk around
the White House inside.

Matt Prestopino:
As the evolution of
the project goes,

we've actually been pushing
beyond the streets and looking

for really more interesting
places to go long-term,

like interiors of spaces
and the White House, right?

Which is a wonderful
place to come.

Diana Skaar:
Right now, Chris and Matt
from the Street View team are

actually pushing around this
trolley that we created to do
interior Street View captures.

Chris Fiock:
That's an absolutely
amazing experience,

to be able to walk
through the White House.

Some incredible sites,
incredible art work.

One of my favorites was the view
out of the Blue Room out to see
the Washington Monument.
This is my first trip to D.C.

To be able to actually see
anything is very, very neat.

Matt Prestopino:
This is going to be great
because we're really going to

open up a lot of the areas that
are viewable to the public to

the world; right, so that
people can actually come in and
virtually explore.

Not only can they explore D.C.,
because we've got great coverage
of D.C. from Street View.

But now they can jump from the
image to the imagery in the

street into the White House and
actually go into and see some of

these famous rooms that,
you know, are referenced in,

you know, as Obama's giving
his latest speech, you know,

and is walking
down the red carpet.

They can actually go into that
room and see exactly where he
was and where he did that.

Diana Skaar:
A couple of the museums have
the ability to have one painting

captured in a very
high resolution image.
We call this the gigapixel.

And what this is is it's
basically an image-capture

using very high
resolution technology.

And then we have computer
technology associated like with

that camera that will then
stitch the pixels together to

create this ultra
high-resolution image that

allows the user to zoom in
at brushstroke-level details.

And we're just really excited
to bring this same experience to

users around the world once we
make this imagery available.

It's almost like you're
getting your own private tour.

title: Behind the Scenes: The Google Art Project at the White House

comments.text: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SIOUhjL5fKI﻿

comments.text:
The US elections are drawing near and more people have their eyes and ears 
on Washington, DC. Back in April we launched indoor imagery of the White 
House: http://goo.gl/0hvZO Oblige your curiousity and tour the presidential 
interior: http://goo.gl/maps/7ee8x ﻿

Let's map the interior of your business, office, or historical piece of

comments.text:
Instead of doing gimmicky crap like this, they should focus on actually 
getting the rest of the world streetview-mapped. It's like they finished 
doing all of america and just stopped giving a fuck.
comments.author: Asbjørn Olling

comments.text:
Let's go  #BehindTheScenes  of our Street View capture at +The White House. 
Take a look at the process that went into creating a 360 degree virtual 
walk through the White House public tour. 
And enjoy the result here: http://goo.gl/6th5p﻿

comments.text:
This is amazing! Can't wait! I've been to the Whitehouse before and it's

comments.author: Ryan Gagnet

comments.text:
This is very cool. However, you should show some respect. At about 1:25 of 
this video, Matt Prestopino from Google refers to the president as simply, 
"Obama". Like him or not, he deserves to be referred to as "President 
Obama", or "the president". It's common courtesy. But I love the video. 
Good stuff!
comments.author: Scott Crevier

comments.text: :P I love it. nice thing. hope to have this one day

comments.text:
Wow! How cool is that? - Huh - I am well pleased. I've toured the Capitol 
building personally. But While I was there the Whitehouse tours weren't 
operating that day. So I left. But I did nevertheless get to see the Cherry 
trees in full white bloom. Gosh I have pictures of that to as well as in 
side the Capitol. Thanks, to everyone for making tis Google tour so 
special. God bless you and God bless the United States of America. Of whom 
I am a well pleased Citizen today.Thanks Ronald. Amen.
